1 1 Check brackets in the code

Input Format. Input contains one string ğ‘† which consists of big and small latin letters, digits, punctuation marks and brackets from the set []{}().
Constraints. The length of ğ‘† is at least 1 and at most 105.
Output Format. If the code in ğ‘† uses brackets correctly, output â€œSuccessâ€ (without the quotes). Otherwise,
output the 1-based index of the first unmatched closing bracket, and if there are no unmatched closing
brackets, output the 1-based index of the first unmatched opening bracket.

2 Compute tree height

Task. You are given a description of a rooted tree. Your task is to compute and output its height. Recall
that the height of a (rooted) tree is the maximum depth of a node, or the maximum distance from a
leaf to the root. You are given an arbitrary tree, not necessarily a binary tree.
Input Format. The first line contains the number of nodes ğ‘›. The second line contains ğ‘› integer numbers
from âˆ’1 to ğ‘› âˆ’ 1 â€” parents of nodes. If the ğ‘–-th one of them (0 â‰¤ ğ‘– â‰¤ ğ‘› âˆ’ 1) is âˆ’1, node ğ‘– is the root,
otherwise itâ€™s 0-based index of the parent of ğ‘–-th node. It is guaranteed that there is exactly one root.
It is guaranteed that the input represents a tree.
Constraints. 1 â‰¤ ğ‘› â‰¤ 105.
Output Format. Output the height of the tree.

3 Network packet processing simulation

Task. You are given a series of incoming network packets, and your task is to simulate their processing.


Input Format. The first line of the input contains the size ğ‘† of the buffer and the number ğ‘› of incoming
network packets. Each of the next ğ‘› lines contains two numbers. ğ‘–-th line contains the time of arrival
ğ´ğ‘– and the processing time ğ‘ƒğ‘– (both in milliseconds) of the ğ‘–-th packet. It is guaranteed that the
sequence of arrival times is non-decreasing (however, it can contain the exact same times of arrival in
milliseconds â€” in this case the packet which is earlier in the input is considered to have arrived earlier).
Constraints. All the numbers in the input are integers. 1 â‰¤ ğ‘† â‰¤ 105; 0 â‰¤ ğ‘› â‰¤ 105; 0 â‰¤ ğ´ğ‘– â‰¤ 106;
0 â‰¤ ğ‘ƒğ‘– â‰¤ 103; ğ´ğ‘– â‰¤ ğ´ğ‘–+1 for 1 â‰¤ ğ‘– â‰¤ ğ‘› âˆ’ 1.
Output Format. For each packet output either the moment of time (in milliseconds) when the processor
began processing it or âˆ’1 if the packet was dropped (output the answers for the packets in the same
order as the packets are given in the input).

4 Extending stack interface

Task. Implement a stack supporting the operations Push(), Pop(), and Max().
Input Format. The first line of the input contains the number ğ‘ of queries. Each of the following ğ‘ lines
specifies a query of one of the following formats: push v, pop, or max.

Output Format. For each max query, output (on a separate line) the maximum value of the stack.

week2. Priority Queues and Disjoint Sets

1 Convert array into heap

Task. The first step of the HeapSort algorithm is to create a heap from the array you want to sort. By the
way, did you know that algorithms based on Heaps are widely used for external sort, when you need
to sort huge files that donâ€™t fit into memory of a computer?
Your task is to implement this first step and convert a given array of integers into a heap. You will
do that by applying a certain number of swaps to the array. Swap is an operation which exchanges
elements ğ‘ğ‘– and ğ‘ğ‘— of the array ğ‘ for some ğ‘– and ğ‘—. You will need to convert the array into a heap using
only ğ‘‚(ğ‘›) swaps, as was described in the lectures. Note that you will need to use a min-heap instead
of a max-heap in this problem.
Input Format. The first line of the input contains single integer ğ‘›. The next line contains ğ‘› space-separated
integers ğ‘ğ‘–.
Constraints. 1 â‰¤ ğ‘› â‰¤ 100 000; 0 â‰¤ ğ‘–, ğ‘— â‰¤ ğ‘› âˆ’ 1; 0 â‰¤ ğ‘0, ğ‘1, . . . , ğ‘ğ‘›âˆ’1 â‰¤ 109. All ğ‘ğ‘– are distinct.
Output Format. The first line of the output should contain single integer ğ‘š â€” the total number of swaps.
ğ‘š must satisfy conditions 0 â‰¤ ğ‘š â‰¤ 4ğ‘›. The next ğ‘š lines should contain the swap operations used
to convert the array ğ‘ into a heap. Each swap is described by a pair of integers ğ‘–, ğ‘— â€” the 0-based
indices of the elements to be swapped. After applying all the swaps in the specified order the array
must become a heap, that is, for each ğ‘– where 0 â‰¤ ğ‘– â‰¤ ğ‘› âˆ’ 1 the following conditions must be true:

    1. If 2ğ‘– + 1 â‰¤ ğ‘› âˆ’ 1, then ğ‘ğ‘– < ğ‘2ğ‘–+1.
    1. If 2ğ‘– + 2 â‰¤ ğ‘› âˆ’ 1, then ğ‘ğ‘– < ğ‘2ğ‘–+2.
      Note that all the elements of the input array are distinct. Note that any sequence of swaps that has
      length at most 4ğ‘› and after which your initial array becomes a correct heap will be graded as correct.

2 Parallel processing

Task. You have a program which is parallelized and uses ğ‘› independent threads to process the given list of ğ‘š
jobs. Threads take jobs in the order they are given in the input. If there is a free thread, it immediately
takes the next job from the list. If a thread has started processing a job, it doesnâ€™t interrupt or stop
until it finishes processing the job. If several threads try to take jobs from the list simultaneously, the
thread with smaller index takes the job. For each job you know exactly how long will it take any thread
to process this job, and this time is the same for all the threads. You need to determine for each job
which thread will process it and when will it start processing.
Input Format. The first line of the input contains integers ğ‘› and ğ‘š.
The second line contains ğ‘š integers ğ‘¡ğ‘– â€” the times in seconds it takes any thread to process ğ‘–-th job.
The times are given in the same order as they are in the list from which threads take jobs.
Threads are indexed starting from 0.
Constraints. 1 â‰¤ ğ‘› â‰¤ 105; 1 â‰¤ ğ‘š â‰¤ 105; 0 â‰¤ ğ‘¡ğ‘– â‰¤ 109.
Output Format. Output exactly ğ‘š lines. ğ‘–-th line (0-based index is used) should contain two spaceseparated
integers â€” the 0-based index of the thread which will process the ğ‘–-th job and the time
in seconds when it will start processing that job.

3 Merging tables

Task. There are ğ‘› tables stored in some database. The tables are numbered from 1 to ğ‘›. All tables share
the same set of columns. Each table contains either several rows with real data or a symbolic link to
another table. Initially, all tables contain data, and ğ‘–-th table has ğ‘Ÿğ‘– rows. You need to perform ğ‘š of
the following operations:

    1. Consider table number ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘›ğ‘–. Traverse the path of symbolic links to get to the data. That is,
      while ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘›ğ‘– contains a symbolic link instead of real data do
      ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘›ğ‘– â† symlink(ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘›ğ‘–)
    1. Consider the table number ğ‘ ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘– and traverse the path of symbolic links from it in the same
      manner as for ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘›ğ‘–.

      and instead of real data put a symbolic link to ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘›ğ‘– into it.
    1. Print the maximum size among all ğ‘› tables (recall that size is the number of rows in the table).
      If the table contains only a symbolic link, its size is considered to be 0.

Input Format. The first line of the input contains two integers ğ‘› and ğ‘š â€” the number of tables in the

The second line of the input contains ğ‘› integers ğ‘Ÿğ‘– â€” the number of rows in the ğ‘–-th table.

ğ‘ ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘– â€” the numbers of the tables to merge.
Constraints. 1 â‰¤ ğ‘›,ğ‘š â‰¤ 100 000; 0 â‰¤ ğ‘Ÿğ‘– â‰¤ 10 000; 1 â‰¤ ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘›ğ‘–, ğ‘ ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘– â‰¤ ğ‘›.
Output Format. For each query print a line containing a single integer â€” the maximum of the sizes of all
tables (in terms of the number of rows) after the corresponding operation.

week4 . Binary Search Trees

1 Binary tree traversals

é¢˜ç›®

Task. You are given a rooted binary tree. Build and output its in-order, pre-order and post-order traversals.
Input Format. The first line contains the number of vertices ğ‘›. The vertices of the tree are numbered
from 0 to ğ‘› âˆ’ 1. Vertex 0 is the root.
The next ğ‘› lines contain information about vertices 0, 1, â€¦, ğ‘›âˆ’1 in order. Each of these lines contains
three integers ğ‘˜ğ‘’ğ‘¦ğ‘–, ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘– and ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡ğ‘– â€” ğ‘˜ğ‘’ğ‘¦ğ‘– is the key of the ğ‘–-th vertex, ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘– is the index of the left
child of the ğ‘–-th vertex, and ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡ğ‘– is the index of the right child of the ğ‘–-th vertex. If ğ‘– doesnâ€™t have
left or right child (or both), the corresponding ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘– or ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡ğ‘– (or both) will be equal to âˆ’1.
Constraints. 1 â‰¤ ğ‘› â‰¤ 105; 0 â‰¤ ğ‘˜ğ‘’ğ‘¦ğ‘– â‰¤ 109; âˆ’1 â‰¤ ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘–, ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡ğ‘– â‰¤ ğ‘› âˆ’ 1. It is guaranteed that the input
represents a valid binary tree. In particular, if ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘– Ì¸= âˆ’1 and ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡ğ‘– Ì¸= âˆ’1, then ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘– Ì¸= ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡ğ‘–. Also,
a vertex cannot be a child of two different vertices. Also, each vertex is a descendant of the root vertex.
Output Format. Print three lines. The first line should contain the keys of the vertices in the in-order
traversal of the tree. The second line should contain the keys of the vertices in the pre-order traversal
of the tree. The third line should contain the keys of the vertices in the post-order traversal of the tree.

2 Is it a binary search tree?

é¢˜ç›®

Task.
You are given a binary tree with integers as its keys. You need to test whether it is a correct binary
search tree. The definition of the binary search tree is the following: for any node of the tree, if its
key is ğ‘¥, then for any node in its left subtree its key must be strictly less than ğ‘¥, and for any node in
its right subtree its key must be strictly greater than ğ‘¥. In other words, smaller elements are to the
left, and bigger elements are to the right. You need to check whether the given binary tree structure
satisfies this condition. You are guaranteed that the input contains a valid binary tree. That is, it is a
tree, and each node has at most two children.

3 Is it a binary search tree? Hard version.

é¢˜ç›®

Task. You are given a binary tree with integers as its keys. You need to test whether it is a correct binary
search tree. Note that there can be duplicate integers in the tree, and this is allowed. The definition of
the binary search tree in such case is the following: for any node of the tree, if its key is ğ‘¥, then for any
node in its left subtree its key must be strictly less than ğ‘¥, and for any node in its right subtree its key
must be greater than or equal to ğ‘¥. In other words, smaller elements are to the left, bigger elements
are to the right, and duplicates are always to the right. You need to check whether the given binary
tree structure satisfies this condition. You are guaranteed that the input contains a valid binary tree.
That is, it is a tree, and each node has at most two children.

1 Problem: Find All Occurrences of a Pattern in a String

In this problem, we ask a simple question: how many times one string occurs as a substring of another?
Recall that different occurrences of a substring can overlap with each other. For example, ATA occurs three
times in CGATATATCCATAG.

  • Task. Find all occurrences of a pattern in a string.
  • Input Format. Strings ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘› and ğºğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘œğ‘šğ‘’.

2 Problem: Construct the Suffix Array of a Long String

string. This will require you to implement an efficient algorithm.

4 Advanced Problem: Construct the Suffix Tree from the Suffix Array

SuffixTree(Text) can be constructed in linear time from SuffixArray(Text) by using the longest common
prefix (LCP) array of Text, LCP(Text), which stores the length of the longest common prefix shared by
consecutive lexicographically ordered suffixes of Text. For example,

week1

1. Problem: Finding an Exit from a Maze

A maze is a rectangular grid of cells with walls between some of adjacent cells.
You would like to check whether there is a path from a given cell to a given
exit from a maze where an exit is also a cell that lies on the border of the maze
(in the example shown to the right there are two exits: one on the left border
and one on the right border). For this, you represent the maze as an undirected
graph: vertices of the graph are cells of the maze, two vertices are connected by
an undirected edge if they are adjacent and there is no wall between them. Then,
to check whether there is a path between two given cells in the maze, it suffices to
check that there is a path between the corresponding two vertices in the graph.
Task. Given an undirected graph and two distinct vertices ğ‘¢ and ğ‘£, check if there is a path between ğ‘¢ and ğ‘£.
Input Format. An undirected graph with ğ‘› vertices and ğ‘š edges. The next line contains two vertices ğ‘¢
and ğ‘£ of the graph.
Constraints. 2 â‰¤ ğ‘› â‰¤ 103; 1 â‰¤ ğ‘š â‰¤ 103; 1 â‰¤ ğ‘¢, ğ‘£ â‰¤ ğ‘›; ğ‘¢ Ì¸= ğ‘£.
Output Format. Output 1 if there is a path between ğ‘¢ and ğ‘£ and 0 otherwise.

Problem: Building Roads to Connect Cities

Task. Given ğ‘› points on a plane, connect them with segments of minimum total length such that there is a
path between any two points. Recall that the length of a segment with endpoints (ğ‘¥1, ğ‘¦1) and (ğ‘¥2, ğ‘¦2)
is equal to

(ğ‘¥ğ‘–, ğ‘¦ğ‘–).
Constraints. 1 â‰¤ ğ‘› â‰¤ 200; âˆ’103 â‰¤ ğ‘¥ğ‘–, ğ‘¦ğ‘– â‰¤ 103 are integers. All points are pairwise different, no three
points lie on the same line.
Output Format. Output the minimum total length of segments. The absolute value of the difference
between the answer of your program and the optimal value should be at most 10âˆ’6. To ensure this,
output your answer with at least seven digits after the decimal point (otherwise your answer, while
being computed correctly, can turn out to be wrong because of rounding issues).

1. Sum of Two Digits

We start from this ridiculously simple problem to show you the
pipeline of reading the problem statement, designing an algorithm, implementing
it, testing and debugging your program, and submitting it to
the grading system.

Output format. The sum of a and b.

    3 Greatest Common Divisor

    The greatest common divisor GCD(ğ‘, ğ‘) of two non-negative integers ğ‘ and ğ‘
    (which are not both equal to 0) is the greatest integer ğ‘‘ that divides both ğ‘ and ğ‘.
    Your goal in this problem is to implement the Euclidean algorithm for computing
    the greatest common divisor.
    Efficient algorithm for computing the greatest common divisor is an important
    basic primitive of commonly used cryptographic algorithms like RSA.

6 Maximum Number of Prizes

You are organizing a funny competition for children. As a prize fund you have ğ‘›
candies. You would like to use these candies for top ğ‘˜ places in a competition
with a natural restriction that a higher place gets a larger number of candies.
To make as many children happy as possible, you are going to find the largest
value of ğ‘˜ for which it is possible.

3 Improving Quick Sort

To force the given implementation of the quick sort algorithm to efficiently process sequences with
few unique elements, your goal is replace a 2-way partition with a 3-way partition. That is, your new
partition procedure should partition the array into three parts: < ğ‘¥ part, = ğ‘¥ part, and > ğ‘¥ part.

4 Number of Inversions

An inversion of a sequence ğ‘0, ğ‘1, . . . , ğ‘ğ‘›âˆ’1 is a pair of indices 0 â‰¤ ğ‘– < ğ‘— < ğ‘› such that ğ‘ğ‘– > ğ‘ğ‘— . The number of inversions of a sequence in some sense measures how close the sequence is to being sorted. For example, a sorted (in non-descending order) sequence contains no inversions at all, while in a sequence sorted in descending order any two elements constitute an inversion (for a total of ğ‘›(ğ‘› âˆ’ 1)/2 inversions).The goal in this problem is to count the number of inversions of a given sequence.

    5 Organizing a Lottery

    You are organizing an online lottery. To participate, a person bets on a single integer. You then draw several ranges of consecutive integers at random.A participantâ€™s payoff then is proportional to the number of ranges that
    contain the participantâ€™s number minus the number of ranges that does not contain it. You need an efficient algorithm for computing the payoffs for all participants. A naive way to do this is to simply scan, for all participants, the
    list of all ranges. However, you lottery is very popular: you have thousands of participants and thousands of ranges. For this reason, you cannot afford a slow naive algorithm.

  9. å¦ä¸€ç§æ–¹æ³•å¯èƒ½æ›´å¿«ä¸€ç‚¹ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ç›´æ¥åˆ©ç”¨äºŒåˆ†æŸ¥æ‰¾ã€‚å¯¹äºå½“å‰ç‚¹p:x,æˆ‘ä»¬æŸ¥æ‰¾æœ‰å¤šå°‘ä¸ªå¤§äºxçš„å·¦ç«¯ç‚¹ï¼Œä¸ªæ•°å³ä¸ºlx,åŒæ—¶æŸ¥æ‰¾å¤§äºç­‰äºxçš„å³ç«¯ç‚¹çš„ä¸ªæ•°ä¸ºrx.åŒ…å«ç‚¹pçš„çº¿æ®µæ•°ä¸ºrx-lx.

    ä»£ç

Let us define the FizzBuzz sequence a1,a2,â€¦

  • If none of the above holds but 5 divides i, ai=Buzz
  • If none of the above holds, ai=i

Find the sum of all numbers among the first N
terms of the FizzBuzz sequence.
